item.content:encoded:
Even when visual perception could be approached from the Newton's perspective, considering the physical light rays being reflected and rejected by surfaces and perceived by the human eyes as a form of energy (emission theory), in 1867 Hermann von Helmholtz coined the term Unconscious inference to describe those pre-rational mechanism that could affect human visual perception. Here are some of those precepts or mechanisms:

  • light comes from above
  • objects are normally not view from below
  • faces are seen (and recognized) upright
  • closer objects can block the view of more distant objects

Using processing to recreate optical illusions on your navigator

Using a p5.js a JavasScript library created by the Processing organization to allow coding an experimentation with visual elements. Using p5.js we can embed our code directly on a website with a little effort.

Here comes six very known illusions, their explanation and implementation using nothing but JavaScript and p5.js

Hering illusion

A geometrical optical illusion discovered by Ewald Hering in which two parallel rects seems curved in the presence of a radial background.

Click on the image to reveal the illusion.

Source code in JavaScript using p5.js

  setup = function () {
    var canvas = createCanvas(500, 500);
    canvas.parent('sketch-holder');
  }
  draw = function () {
    background(255);
    translate(250, 250);
    if (!mouseIsPressed) {
      stroke(0, 0, 100);
      i = 0
      for (i; i < 490; i = i + 10) {
        rotate(5);
        line(0, 0, 400, 400);
      }
      rotate(-245)
    }
    strokeWeight(3);
    stroke(200, 0, 0);
    translate(-250, -250);
    line(200, 0, 200, 500);
    line(300, 0, 300, 500);
  }
